Derek,

This doesn't directly address your questions but have you checkout 
out the Pareto Coevolution stuff from Pollack's group.  Their 
complete paper list is here:

http://helen.cs-i.brandeis.edu/papers/

But the stuff on Pareto coevolution can give you a lot of insight 
into what coevolution is really trying to do and what it needs to do 
it.

As an aside, I think coevolving good board game strategies is really 
hard.  The problem is they learn totally bizarre strategies that 
work against each other but have little relation to the real world.  
It may be necessary to fold in some kind of hand-coded player into 
e.g. the hall of fame, to keep them sane.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> Hi all,
> 
> Philip and I have been discussing the next experimental domain we'd
> like to explore, and we've decided on Go-moku (probably starting 
with
> a smaller size, e.g., 7x7, and scaling up to 15x15).
> 
> For our GECCO paper, we used direct evolution, i.e., we calculated 
the
> fitness of our networks each generation based on performance versus
> hand-coded players.  But we're very interested in coevolutionary
> techniques, as this seems to be the logical future for domains in
> which good computer opponents don't exist.
> 
> I don't know if any of you have read Panait and Luke's paper 
comparing
> K-Random Opponents coevolution and SET (Single-Elimination 
Tournament)
> coevolution:
> 
> http://cs.gmu.edu/~sean/papers/twocompetitive.pdf
> 
> Their findings suggest that both of these approaches work well, and
> may be dependent on the amount of randomness in the domain.
> 
> They also point out that most professional sports rely on a
> combination of these approaches, which they broadly categorize as
> "renaissance" and "duel" approaches.  Most pro sports have a 
regular
> season, in which teams play a broad sample of other teams.  Those 
with
> the best overall records at the end of the season enter a
> single-elimination tournament to decide who is "the best".
> 
> Other sports, like tennis, are almost exclusively SET-based.  I'm
> wondering if the group has any thoughts on these types of dynamics,
> and if anyone knows of any theoretical work done on these dynamics.
> 
> Also, what are the relative advantages to double-elimination, 
versus
> single-elimination?  It's twice as computationally expensive, but 
how
> well does it contribute to the coevolutionary dynamics?  K-Random 
Opps
> seems more biologically plausible, but SET and DET are much more
> efficient, and seem easier to extend with Hall of Famers.  If they
> work as well or better in general, shouldn't they be the preferred
> method?
> 
> Derek
